docs.text: The phase operator in quantum mechanics We will state: suppose the position variable of a free particle is quantized by the unit \Delta x = \frac{\hbar}{mc}, the momentum variable should be, in general a nonlinear function of the position derivative: \frac{\hat{p}}{mc} = \tan{\hat{\phi}} where the argument of the tangent function is the phase operator \varphi = -i\Delta x \frac{\partial}{\partial x}.
docs.title: Phase Operator

docs.text: We will state: suppose the position variable of a free particle is quantized by the unit \Delta x = \frac{\hbar}{mc}, the momentum variable should be, in general a nonlinear function of the position derivative: \frac{\hat{p}}{mc} = \tan{\hat{\phi}} where the argument of the tangent function is the phase operator \varphi = -i\Delta x \frac{\partial}{\partial x}.
docs.title: The phase operator in quantum mechanics

docs.text: Who are you Dojyo? I am a Japanese, living in Tokyo. Dojyo means a kind of Japanese 'Loach' rather than my actual name. But I use this particular noun as me anyway. I enjoy thinking about the certain aspect of quantum mechanics for my spare times. This is what I should say now. Good day ¥(**)/
docs.title: Who are you
